title_sort: james s. stillwell to walt whitman, 5 july 1864
title: James S. Stillwell to Walt Whitman, 5 July 1864
text: Dear FriendI take the present time to write a few lines to you to let you know how I am I am very well at presant[present] my wound is a doing very well now but it is worse than it was when I left armory Square it commence to get worse About the tenth of June it was so fore About three weeks that I did not go out of the ward but it is A gitting[getting] better again now I am now at chestnuthill Hospital philadelphia[Philadelphia] this hospital is About ten miles from the city of Philadelphia this is A very pleasant place here there is A grove on one side of the hospital and A bowling in the grove and A half A dozen Swings but I dont[don't] like it as well here as I did their there is forty seven(47) wards to this hospital each wards has 60 beds in some of the new york boys has been transferred to new york from here but I didnt[didn't] of happen to be one of them thomas[Thomas] Flood is here he is ward master of this ward he sends his best wishes to you I had a letter from home last friday[Friday] they was all well then and mother Sends her best respect to you I have not been home yet but I expect to go home in About two weeks on A furlough you musnt[musn't] think hard of me because I havent[haven't] write to you before, pleas write Soon So no more at presant[present] from your affectionate Frienddirect your letter to Mower Hospital Chestnut Hill Ward (20) James S. Stillwell to Walt Whitman, 5 July 1864
